items.title: Stellar Motion Exploration
items.label: Stellar Motion Exploration
items.description:
Guided by MATLAB’s OnRamps Astronomy Spectroscopy module, I developed a MATLAB script to measure stellar velocities via the Doppler shift of the Hydrogen-alpha absorption line.

I began by importing wavelength-vs-intensity spectra for seven stars and plotting each spectrum. Using MATLAB’s min function, I identified the Hα trough—where hydrogen atoms absorb most strongly—and compared its observed wavelength (λₒᵦₛ) to the laboratory reference of 656.28 nm.

I then computed the fractional shift,

z = (λₒᵦₛ/656.28nm) -1

and the corresponding radial speed,

v = z x C

A positive z (λₒᵦₛ > 656.28 nm) indicates redshift (receding), while a negative z (λₒᵦₛ < 656.28 nm) indicates blueshift (approaching).

By looping through each star’s data structure with for and if logic, the code automatically extracted, analyzed, and classified all spectra. Finally, I overlaid the results on a single plot—using bold solid lines for redshifted stars and dashed lines for blueshifted ones—to provide a clear visual summary of stellar motion relative to Earth.
